awd_titl_txt: Active turbulence from polymer additives: Theory, modeling and high fidelity simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
Complex fluids define a wide variety of fluids encountered in pharmaceutical, food, petroleum, biological industries. The manner in which many of these fluids flow challenges the predictive models currently used by engineers and scientists for the design and optimization of engineering applications and understanding of physical phenomena. For instance, the addition of polymers in a liquid, the complex fluid of interest here, can reduce drag when transporting water or oil in pipes, but also increase heat transfer and mixing in microfluidics. It can promote formation of emulsion between two immiscible solutions under conditions at which an emulsion is not otherwise possible, or it can control droplet sizes in spray to improve agricultural irrigation or combustion in liquid fuel injection engines. Polymer additives offer, and in some of the applications mentioned above, deliver large returns on investment, however the modeling or predictability of these phenomena remains poor owing to the absence of sound theoretical understanding. The main objective of this project is to develop high-fidelity predictive computational models that will benefit a large range of industries dealing with complex fluids. The project will also have an education component, encompassing training of a graduate student in complex fluid dynamics and numerical simulation, and the development of open-source tools used in turbulence and computational fluid dynamics courses.

Polymer additives offer a unique window of investigation into complex energy transfers involving direct and inverse energy cascades between large and small scales, between turbulence and polymer molecules. Polymer additives have been identified as responsible for elastic turbulence in inertialess flows, elasto-inertial turbulence in subcritical wall-bounded flows and drag reduction in supercritical wall-bounded flows up to an asymptotic, non-laminar state called maximum drag reduction. None of these states are well understood. The objectives of the proposed research effort are to fully characterize the statistical properties of the above mentioned turbulent states, to investigate the energy transfer between polymers and flows in all turbulent states in search for universal properties and to leverage the cumulative sum of knowledge acquired within this project into high fidelity computational models of non-Newtonian turbulent flows at very low to large Reynolds numbers. The numerical simulations used to support this project are state-of-the-art viscoelastic direct numerical simulations developed to capture the targeted dynamics. This project will create a unique and extensive database of elastic and elasto-inertial turbulent flows which will be made available to the scientific community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to investigate a recently discovered state of turbulence, called elasto-inertial turbulence (EIT). Turbulence is one of the greatest challenges in engineering, physics and mathematics. Turbulence is everywhere, from climate, to combustion, to air quality, to mixing milk in a coffee cup. For the most part, the theory of turbulence has been well established since the 60's-70's. The existing theory has led to models that can simulate the drag around a plane with a high degree of accuracy. There is little to discover in the field of turbulence, yet what remains poorly understood is extremely complex, and unfortunately is the source of significant uncertainties in our simulations and predictions of complex turbulent flows, such as flows with strong mixing or flows with unusual viscosity dynamics, like polymer flows. 

 

EIT is one of those rare uncharted territories in turbulence. Diluted polymers in a liquid flow can create a unique state of turbulence or chaotic state, called elasto inertial turbulence (EIT) or elastic turbulence (ET) different from the turbulence observed without polymers. ET was discovered first in 2000 in flows dominated by viscous forces and with significant curvature. Discovered in 2010 by the PI of the present project, EIT occurs in straight flows where inertial forces (forces that causes the fluid to move) are equal or larger than viscous forces. EIT has the power to make a flow chaotic at regimes that the same flow without polymers would be laminar. EIT also exists in fully developed turbulent flows, competing with another well-known effect of polymer additives: turbulence reduction. 

 

The project used high fidelity simulations to achieve key advances in understanding EIT and potentially ET. The bulk of the effort was centered on flows in channels at various Reynolds number, a non-dimensional number which is the ratio of inertial to viscous forces, the two mechanisms that dictate the regime of the flow (laminar, transitional or turbulent). The project supported the most extensive exploration to-date of the parameter space of the model of polymer dynamics used in simulations.

 

The first outcome was the discovery of the first exact coherent structure of EIT in two-dimensional channel flows. Exact coherent structures (ECS) define fundamental states of flows. In inertial turbulence (without polymers), flows may be observed to fluctuate between different ECS. Over the past two decades, the community has increasingly focused on ECS to better understand, model and control turbulence. Simulated polymeric two-dimensional channel flows with polymer were found to exist in four distinct regimes, three of which under the influence or entirely governed by the first ECS, the arrowhead.

 

The second outcome identified the scales at which energy transfers between polymer and flow dynamics sustain EIT. The project demonstrated a long-standing conjecture: Energy from flow perturbations at larger scales sustain polymer stress, and polymer stress structures at smaller scales feed flow perturbations. Of great importance to the theory of EIT, simulations showed that energy transfer from polymers to flow occur around the Kolmogorov scale, which in inertial turbulence is the smallest scale, or viscous scale. Another critical observation was the need to simulate polymer scales smaller than the Kolmogorov scale in order to simulate EIT. 

 

The third outcome was the discovery of a new instability. This viscous diffusive instability is conjectured to be universal to EIT and ET, and is also speculated to play a role in the energy transfer between polymer and flow dynamics.

 

The fourth outcome was a significant progress in the fidelity and robustness of the simulations of EIT and ET polymer flows. Polymer models used in numerical simulations are notoriously challenging to resolved with precision owing to the large gradients of stress they produce. Advances in the understanding of EIT and ET derived from the first three outcomes became guiding principles to define the constraints necessary to use numerical methods with the highest fidelity for the simulation for EIT and ET.

 

The fifth and final outcome was the demonstration of the existence of EIT in flows other than the channel flow, which opens new avenues to study EIT and complete its theory.

 

The intellectual merits of the project were definitive and crucial advances in the theory of elasto inertial turbulence and elastic turbulence and their simulations. The discovered dynamics shed light on energy transfer from small to larger scales in turbulence, an important contribution to the broader impacts of this project. Other broader impacts to note are (i) the education of three graduate students who were able to leverage the skills and knowledge acquired in this project to further their career in STEM, (ii) the translation of numerical methods into course materials used to teach engineering and physics students about efficient and high-fidelity scientific computing, and (iii) the development of new algorithms of polymer flow simulation that could benefit multiple industries, including food, paint and plastic.

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2023
Modified by: Yves Dubief
